Let me be very clear. The draft doesn't phase out x-, they were never meant=
 to be used anyway, in any litterature, anywhere. People taht use X- are in=
 infraction of HTTP and are only doing it because of cargo-cult development=
 where the saw someone else do it and they repeat the same crap over and ov=
er again.

You can't phase out something that was never to be used on the i=
nternet anyway. The draft is just a louder voice to communicate better to t=
hose that never read the http spec that x- is daft.

I agree that thi=
s was the original intent, but the fact of the matter is that the "extensio=
n use case" has escaped into the wild.

RFC3864 exists for a reason.  It ta=
lks about experimental headers, but it also talks about a provisional repos=
itory containing headers that have been "adopted ad-hoc to address a locall=
y occurring requirement; some of these have found widespread use"

Realizin=
g that we are all treading water until HTTPbis is finished,
I'm looking for=
 comments from people who felt the need to use headers in this way.
